climbs.name: Where have all the cowboys gone

content.description: Thin reachy crux in the middle that clocked in around V4.  Not too bad otherwise.
content.location: 3rd route in from the right (just left of arete climb).  Start on top of the block.

content.description: This is an excellent link up which has 4 distinct cruxes. Start out left on The Scalp and climb up through the crux (do not clip bolt) and exit right crossing through on two finger pockets. Now you're on last dance, clip one bolt and climb up into the crux. Match the crimp rail after the block pinch (do not clip this bolt)and traverse right into Teepee. Finish it up on Teepee Creeper. Awesome movement! SACK UP!
content.location: On left side of the wars wall

content.description: by comparison to Indian wars wall this is a slab.   Good clips and a crux is Mid tophalf on perfect clean   black rock,with sequential wild pinches and cool rad moves.
content.location: One route to right of last dance, starts on dirty    sloping belay above and lookers left of Indian wars wall 15 feet,    rope bag recommended

content.description: Climb a mellow slab for 3 bolts to the steeper black headwall. Fire a little crux, followed by sustained technical climbing to the anchor.    Just as good as Last Dance and Teepee Creeper!   Ain't over till its over!
content.location: 2nd route from the left. Between the 5.8 and Last Dance.

content.description: Start on a ledge that is just to the left of the second bolt on Battlecry.  Start pulling on a small sidepull and then continue up making long moves.  The climbing is technical, offering ledges and shallow pockets.  You will come to an awkward sidepull/pinch and some good feet.  After this intial cruxy move you will encounter a left-hand mono.  Pull off the mono and either go to a big right hand or use the small intermediate before.  At this point, you can either top it out the same as Battlecry moving right, or I have been told by Spearfish elders you can move straight left using the the Last of the Mohicans holds.  This route is very, very good.
content.location: Apparently, the name came from the obvious mono that has chalk lining it.  You can see it from the ground.  Supposedly, it is like a bullet hole.

content.description: Orphans of War is a crescendo of interesting pockets and hard to see feet that leads to a finale of edges and a big jug at the end. Well placed bolts make for easy clipping and fun rides on this slightly overhanging wall.
content.location: four routes right of Last of the Mohicans

content.description: Crux is at the top where the holds aren't as good.  Watch out for poison ivy.
content.protection: Four bolts to two cold shut anchors
content.location: The routs starts behind a small tree.  It shares a start with Little Big Man.  It is the left of the two.

climbs.name: Last of the Mohicans
climbs.fa: Greg Parker, equipped by Pete deLannoy

content.description: Perfect pockets and jugs watch out for nesting birds.
Exposed climbing following the arete. Good holds most of the wayÂ
content.location: Follows the arete left of the main wall. Shares first bolt with 'Save the Last Bullet'

content.description:
With 10 bolts to clip this is one of the longer and more technical routes at the Indian Wars Wall. 

  This route is often overlooked but well worth spending some time on. Has been known to leave many a visiting climber, and local alike, hanging around wondering just what they are doing wrong. 

  Get on it! Get found guilty of being too over-confident and get a good lesson in what it means to climb at Spearfish Canyon.
content.protection: bring quick draws and good technique
content.location: Second route from the right hand side of the wall.

content.description: Start by climbing the widely spaced pockets up the tan rock toward a small shelf. The beginning can feel a bit scary the first time up, since the climbing goes back and forth a bit and there isn't a ton of bolts. At around bolt #4 or so, the good pockets give way to small edges that lead up to the bomber black rock that has the route's crimper crux and the exciting finish.    The last four bolts of this route are amazing (in my humble opinion). This was the last route I put in before moving to Salt Lake, hence the name.
content.location: This route climbs up the center of the "Little Big Man Wall" (I don't know if people are calling it that. I think it's fitting). This wall flanks the main Indian Wars wall to the left.

content.description: This route is different from anything else on the wall. A deceiving field of popcorn textured pockets in the first half binds you to the gibbet and a series of sidepulls at a bulge in the second half mercilessly executes the hangin'.
content.location: The furthest route to the climber's right at Indian Wars, this route starts on a dirty ledge separate from the blocks in front of the wall proper.

climbs.name: Blood Brother
climbs.fa: Nate Renner, equipped by Pete deLannoy

content.description: This is a cruiser line of pockets leading up a beautiful chunk of rock to a big reach at the high crux that finishes on edges and ledges.
content.protection: 7ish bolts to chains with biners   stick clip recommended
content.location: Just to the climber's left of Orphans of War. Furthest route to climbers left that still starts on the big block on the right side of the wall.

content.description: Rock your way up a swath of pockets and ledges on blonde rock. Enjoy the crushing decibels of pulling multiple roofs. The best thing about this route is when most routes stop at ten this one goes all the way to eleven.
content.location: Hike 75 feet north of the Indian Wars Wall towards a huge, blonde buttress with obvious roofs. Block and Roll is the line of bolts to the left.

content.description: Stick the 1st and get after it to the 3rd. Cool dihedral climbing takes you out right to a good rest. Pull the steep block on a great heel. Feel the Power! Pumpy rest before the black head wall. Quality
content.location: Blocky steep wall right of wars wall. Rightmost route. Left route is Block and Roll 12b

content.description: Starts in the middle of the wall down low.  Stick clip the first bolts.  Start pulling on some good pockets up to a long reach where you will find some goods holds.  After some pristine pocket climbing, you will enter the "top" crux, which consists of shallow pockets and adjusting the feet to make a long reach to a good left hand, which has been known to crunch the left index finger.  Then you have one more long move to a right hand slot.  I recommend skipping the bolt that is at the left hand.  It tends to be difficult to clip and the ride is clean.  Besides, this will make the last hard move more committing.  Top out to a large ledge with anchors.  This is one of the best routes in the entire canyon, and possibly in the whole universe.
Beautiful Streaked wall, slightly overhung.  Pockets, slots, monos, and jugs!  Perfect Routes.  Thanks to all who developed this area!!!
